str2: Paul, Paulus. Of Latin origin; Paulus, the name of a Roman and of an apostle.

parse: Verb - Aorist Participle Active - Nominative Masculine Singular
str2: From pros and meno; to stay further, i.e. Remain in a place, with a person; figuratively, to adhere to, persevere in.
From hiko; competent, i.e. Ample or fit.
(a) of time: still, yet, even now, (b) of degree: even, further, more, in addition. Perhaps akin to etos; 'yet, ' still.
A day, the period from sunrise to sunset.

parse: Verb - Aorist Participle Middle - Nominative Masculine Singular
str2: To withdraw from, take leave of, renounce, send away.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
A brother, member of the same religious community, especially a fellow-Christian. A brother near or remote.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
From the primary kapto; the head, literally or figuratively.

parse: Verb - Aorist Participle Middle - Nominative Masculine Singular
str2: To shear, cut the hair of; mid: I cut my own hair, have my hair cut. A primary verb; to shear.
In, on, among. A primary preposition denoting position, and instrumentality, i.e. A relation of rest; 'in, ' at, on, by, etc.
Cenchreae, the port of Corinth on the Saronic Gulf. Probably from kegchros; Cenchreae, a port of Corinth.
For. A primary particle; properly, assigning a reason.
From euchomai; properly, a wish, expressed as a petition to God, or in votive obligation.

parse: Verb - Imperfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: To have, hold, possess. Including an alternate form scheo skheh'-o; a primary verb; to hold.

parse: Verb - Imperfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: To sail out (of harbor), sail away. From ek and pleo; to depart by ship.
A primary preposition; to or into, of place, time, or purpose; also in adverbial phrases.
Syria, a great Roman imperial province, united with Cilicia. Probably of Hebrew origin; Syria, a region of Asia.
With. A primary preposition denoting union; with or together.
Diminutive of Priska; Priscilla, a Christian woman.
And, even, also, namely.
Probably for Latin aquila; Akulas, an Israelite.
